text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to note that French courts (as supervisory courts of the Paris seat) apply a minimal-intervention standard when reviewing arbitral awards under Code de proc√©dure civile Article 1520. The candidate answer addresses the French legal framework extensively in Section III.B.2 and III.B.3, noting that French law is among the most arbitration-friendly and that French courts are reluctant to set aside international awards (citing Putrabali). While it does not explicitly quote Article 1520 and label the standard as 'minimal-intervention,' the entire discussion of French law's deference to the tribunal's autonomy and the narrow grounds for annulment under Article 1520 CPC strongly implies and supports this concept, which is central to defending the award's validity at the seat.", "criterion_id": "5eff5275-704c-43f4-b84b-07386550cd36"}
